childhood_context.html:
Childhood: {{BIRTH_YEAR}}-1990

You were born the year the first test-tube baby arrived and disco was still, somehow, a thing. Louise Brown's birth made headlines in July. Your parents watched with a mixture of wonder and horror as science did something that sounded like science fiction. Forty-six years later, IVF is routine. Progress moves fast when you're not paying attention.

Your childhood happened against a backdrop of Cold War anxiety that never quite went away. You were two when Reagan was elected, promising morning in America while stockpiling nuclear weapons. You practiced duck-and-cover drills at school. Adults spoke about 'the Russians' in hushed tones. Nuclear annihilation felt like a real possibility, and you learned to live with that low hum of existential dread before you could fully articulate what it was.

You were eight when the Challenger exploded. You probably watched it live in your classroom, one of millions of kids who saw Christa McAuliffe and six other astronauts die on national television. That moment crystallized something: the future wasn't guaranteed. Progress could literally blow up in your face. You went back to class after, because that's what everyone did in 1986. Trauma wasn't processed—it was absorbed.

By the time you were eleven, the Berlin Wall came down. You watched people take sledgehammers to concrete on the evening news. The Cold War you'd been raised to fear just... ended. Not with nuclear fire, but with sledgehammers and champagne. You were thirteen when the Soviet Union collapsed entirely. The world your parents grew up in disappeared while you were still a kid.

Your childhood was the last truly analog era. No internet, no cell phones, no GPS. If you got lost, you stayed lost until you found a payphone. If you wanted to know something, you went to the library. Entertainment was three TV channels, a VCR if you were lucky, and whatever the local video store had in stock. Boredom was normal. Silence was normal. Being unreachable was normal.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Generation X

You're Generation X, born between 1965 and 1980. The 'X' was supposed to represent an unknown variable—a generation too slippery to define. Douglas Coupland popularized the term in 1991, and it stuck, mostly because nobody had a better idea.

Your generation is roughly 65 million Americans, sandwiched between the massive Boomer cohort and the even larger Millennial wave. You're the middle child of generations—overlooked, underestimated, and quietly getting things done while everyone argues about the others.

Gen X was defined by what you didn't have: stay-at-home moms (they went to work), parental supervision (you were latchkey kids), job security (layoffs became normal), pension plans (401(k)s replaced them). You learned independence early because nobody was watching. You came home to an empty house, made your own snacks, did your homework without help, and figured it out.

The defining cultural moment for your generation was the end of idealism. You watched Watergate's aftermath, the Iran hostage crisis, the Challenger disaster, Iran-Contra. Authority figures lied. Institutions failed. The lesson was clear: don't trust anyone in charge, and definitely don't expect them to save you.

Gen X invented cynicism as a lifestyle. Irony was your defense mechanism. Sincerity was suspect. You rolled your eyes at Boomer optimism because you'd seen where optimism got people. You weren't pessimists—you were realists who'd learned early that the cavalry wasn't coming.

Your generation pioneered work-life balance, not because you believed in it ideologically, but because you watched your parents sacrifice everything for companies that laid them off anyway. Why kill yourself for a job that won't return the favor? Gen X quietly normalized leaving work at 5pm, taking vacations, and not making your career your entire identity.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year Grease dominated box offices and the Bee Gees owned the radio. Saturday Night Fever was still packing theaters. Disco was at its apex, which meant its collapse was imminent. By the time you were three, disco was dead, and everyone pretended they'd never liked it.

Superman: The Movie came out in 1978, convincing audiences that a man could fly. Christopher Reeve became the definitive superhero before superhero movies became a trillion-dollar industry. The film was sincere in a way that would be impossible today—no irony, no deconstruction, just earnest heroism. You were born in the last year that kind of sincerity was commercially viable.

Your childhood was peak Saturday morning cartoons. Transformers, G.I. Joe, He-Man, Thundercats—shows that existed primarily to sell toys, but you didn't care because they were awesome. You probably still have opinions about which Transformer was the best. Nobody asked, but you'd tell them.

MTV launched when you were three, and by the time you were old enough to care, music videos were essential. You watched Michael Jackson moonwalk on Motown 25. You saw Madonna roll around on stage at the VMAs. Prince made purple cool. Music wasn't just something you heard—it was something you watched.

Your teenage years were the era of John Hughes. The Breakfast Club, Sixteen Candles, Ferris Bueller—these movies understood that being a teenager was both ridiculous and deadly serious. They captured suburban Gen X adolescence with an accuracy that still holds up, problematic elements and all.

Nirvana broke when you were thirteen. Grunge killed hair metal overnight. Suddenly, flannel and angst were in, and glossy production was out. 'Smells Like Teen Spirit' was your generation's anthem—a song about being bored and confused, sung by someone who was bored and confused. It was perfect.

By the time you hit your twenties, the internet was emerging, but you experienced the full cultural shift from analog to digital as an adult. You remember the before times. You remember when phones were attached to walls and music came on discs. That perspective makes you the last generation fluent in both worlds.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born the year the first commercial cellular network launched in Japan. Nobody in America had cell phones yet. Your family had one phone, attached to the wall by a cord, and if someone was on it, everyone else waited. Long distance cost money. You kept calls short.

Apple released the Apple II in 1977, one year before your birth. Personal computers existed, but they were exotic—hobbyist toys, not household necessities. You probably didn't touch a computer until elementary school, and when you did, it was a green-screened monstrosity that did almost nothing useful.

The VCR was your generation's transformative technology. Suddenly, you could record television. You could watch movies at home. You could pause, rewind, fast-forward through commercials. Time-shifting was revolutionary. Your family probably had VCR tapes scattered everywhere, labeled in handwriting nobody could read.

You were seventeen when Windows 95 launched. That was the moment personal computers stopped being complicated and started being inevitable. Suddenly, everyone needed one. The interface was intuitive enough that normal people could use it without a manual. Your parents bought one for 'the family,' which meant you used it while they watched.

You were twenty when Google launched. Twenty-two when Napster upended the music industry. Twenty-three when the dot-com bubble burst. You entered adulthood just as the internet was becoming essential, which meant you learned to use it as a tool rather than growing up inside it.

You were twenty-nine when the iPhone launched. You were already an adult with a career and maybe a mortgage when smartphones took over. You adapted, obviously—you're not a dinosaur—but you remember life before everyone had a computer in their pocket. You remember being bored without a screen to fill the void. You remember what silence felt like.

This makes you the generation that bridges the analog and digital worlds. You can troubleshoot a VCR and a smartphone. You understand why people under thirty have never left a voicemail. You're fluent in both languages, which gives you perspective that younger people lack and older people envy.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were four months old when 918 people died in Jonestown, Guyana. Jim Jones convinced his followers to drink cyanide-laced Flavor Aid, and the phrase 'drinking the Kool-Aid' entered the lexicon. You don't remember it, but it defined how your generation thinks about cults, charisma, and the danger of true believers.

The Camp David Accords were signed in September 1978, the same year you were born. Egypt and Israel made peace. It felt like progress. It was progress, even if the broader Middle East remained a mess for the next five decades. You've never known a world where that region wasn't in some kind of crisis.

You were two when Reagan was shot, four when he declared morning in America, eight when Iran-Contra broke. Authority figures kept failing, kept lying, kept getting caught. Watergate was before your time, but its aftermath shaped everything. You learned early that politicians couldn't be trusted, which made the disillusionment easier—you never had illusions to begin with.

The Challenger disaster happened when you were eight. January 28, 1986. You probably watched in school, along with millions of other kids who'd been told space travel was routine now, safe, inspiring. Seventy-three seconds after launch, it exploded. The teacher you were supposed to watch teach from space was gone. You went back to class afterward because that's what kids did. Nobody offered counseling.

You were eleven when the Berlin Wall fell. Twenty-three during 9/11. You were old enough to have adult context for the attacks—you weren't a child processing trauma, you were an adult watching the world change. You saw the towers fall and understood immediately that everything was different now. The wars that followed lasted your entire thirties.

You were thirty during the 2008 financial crisis. Unlike Millennials who graduated into the wreckage, you were established enough to weather it—probably. Your 401(k) cratered. Your house lost value. But you had a job, maybe, and you held on. The recovery was slow, but you'd already learned that recoveries were always slow.

By forty-two, you were in a pandemic. COVID hit when you were established, mid-career, possibly with kids at home doing remote school while you worked remotely yourself. You managed, because Gen X always manages. Nobody asked if you were okay. They never do.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You entered the workforce around 2000, just in time for the dot-com crash. The 'new economy' that was supposed to make everyone rich evaporated. Companies that had never turned a profit collapsed overnight. Stock options became worthless. The message was clear: get-rich-quick was a lie, and the traditional career path your parents described wasn't available either.

Your generation invented the concept of 'free agency' in careers because loyalty didn't pay. You watched your parents' generation get laid off after decades of service. You learned that companies would discard you the moment it was convenient. So you stopped being loyal back. Job-hopping wasn't disloyalty—it was self-preservation.

You're the generation that normalized work-life balance, not as an aspiration but as a boundary. You saw what workaholism did to Boomers—the heart attacks, the divorces, the layoffs that came anyway. You decided that killing yourself for a company that wouldn't return the favor was stupid. You leave at 5pm. You take your vacation days. You're not apologizing for it.

By your thirties, you were in management, which meant dealing with Millennial employees who expected feedback, recognition, and purpose. You found this baffling. Nobody gave you feedback. Nobody recognized you. Purpose was a luxury you couldn't afford. But you adapted, because adapting is what Gen X does. You learned to manage up and down simultaneously.

Your forties are your peak earning years. You have authority now—maybe a C-suite title, maybe not, but enough seniority to make decisions. The challenge is that you're managing people who think email is outdated while reporting to people who think email is cutting-edge. You're the translator between generations, which is exhausting but necessary.

Remote work, which COVID normalized, suits you fine. You've always been self-directed. You don't need supervision to stay productive—you've been unsupervised since you were ten. Working from home just means fewer unnecessary meetings and more actual work getting done.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You're the generation that experienced every major shift in how relationships form and function. You met partners in person, through friends, at bars—the old ways. Then you watched online dating emerge, first as a stigma, then as a norm. You probably tried it somewhere along the way, even if you didn't admit it to anyone.

Your communication evolution spans the entire history of personal technology. You passed notes in class. You talked on landlines for hours. You got your first email account in college, maybe. You texted awkwardly on flip phones, pecking out messages with T9. Now you communicate primarily through screens, but you remember when communication required effort, planning, and patience.

Marriage and family happened on your timeline, not society's. Your generation delayed marriage compared to Boomers, but not as dramatically as Millennials. Some of you married young and divorced young. Some of you waited until your thirties. Some of you opted out entirely. Gen X normalized all of these choices because you'd already learned that following the script didn't guarantee happiness.

If you have kids, they're probably Gen Z or Gen Alpha. You're raising digital natives while being analog immigrants yourself. You set screen time limits while being unsure if screen time limits even matter. You're stricter than your own parents were—no latchkey kids for your generation—but you wonder if the hovering is worse than the neglect.

Your friendships are deep but low-maintenance. You don't need to talk every day—you can pick up where you left off after months of silence. You have group chats but you don't feel obligated to respond immediately. You understand that adults have lives, and presence isn't measured in message frequency.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You entered the workforce during relative prosperity, then watched it collapse. Twice. The dot-com bust in 2000 and the financial crisis in 2008 bracketed your late twenties and early thirties. You learned that economic stability is an illusion, that markets crash, that safety nets have holes.

Your relationship with money is pragmatic bordering on paranoid. You save because you've seen how fast everything can disappear. You invest conservatively because you remember watching portfolios evaporate. You have an emergency fund because you know emergencies aren't hypothetical—they're inevitable.

You probably own a house, unlike many Millennials, because you bought before prices went completely insane. Maybe you bought in 2000, or 2005, or even 2010 during the post-crash slump. Your timing was better, not because you were smarter, but because you were older when the windows opened. Generational wealth is about timing as much as talent.

Your retirement planning is realistic but grim. You don't expect Social Security to be there in its current form. You know pensions are extinct. Your 401(k) is the plan, supplemented by whatever you've managed to save on the side. You'll probably work longer than you want to, but shorter than Millennials will have to.

You're the sandwich generation financially—potentially supporting aging parents while still raising kids or helping adult children who can't afford to launch. Your resources stretch in both directions. This isn't unique to Gen X, but you're hitting it now, in your forties and fifties, with particular intensity.

The wealth gap between generations is real, and you fall in the middle. You're better off than Millennials, worse off than Boomers. You had more opportunities than the people who came after, fewer than the people who came before. You're not rich, but you're stable—if stability exists anymore.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your greatest strength is self-reliance. Your greatest weakness is also self-reliance. You learned to handle everything alone, which means you're terrible at asking for help. You'd rather struggle in silence than admit you need support. This is unhealthy, and you know it, but knowing it doesn't make it easier to change.

Gen X cynicism, once a survival mechanism, has calcified into something less useful. You're so used to assuming the worst that you sometimes miss genuine opportunities for change. Your ironic distance protects you from disappointment, but it also protects you from engagement. Caring is risky, so you don't. That's a problem.

You're dismissive of younger generations in ways you'd hate if you noticed. You mock Millennials for their sensitivity, Gen Z for their anxiety, everyone for their need for validation. You forget that they're dealing with problems you didn't face—worse economics, worse climate, worse job prospects. Your 'I figured it out, so should they' attitude ignores how much the landscape has shifted.

You've normalized overwork as virtue. Yes, you set boundaries, but you also pride yourself on being self-sufficient to a fault. You take on too much because asking for help feels like weakness. You burn out quietly, recover quietly, and burn out again. This pattern isn't sustainable, but you've never known anything else.

Your generation is politically disengaged compared to Boomers and younger voters. You vote, mostly, but you don't organize, don't run for office, don't show up at town halls. You're cynical about the system's ability to change, so you don't try to change it. This becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy: nothing changes because people like you don't push for change.

The independence you learned as latchkey kids has its shadow side. You struggle to build community, to rely on neighbors, to create the social safety nets that used to exist. You're islands, self-sufficient but isolated. In a crisis, you survive alone, but you might thrive better together—if you could bring yourself to ask.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s ({{TWENTIES_START}}-{{TWENTIES_END}}): You graduated into an economy that was about to implode. The dot-com bubble created illusions of easy wealth, then burst spectacularly in 2000. You found your footing during uncertainty, learned to adapt, and discovered that career paths weren't linear anymore. This was your decade of establishing yourself while the ground kept shifting beneath you.

Your 30s ({{THIRTIES_START}}-{{THIRTIES_END}}): The 2008 financial crisis hit when you were thirty, just as you might have been buying a house, starting a family, or finally feeling stable. You weathered it—Gen X always weathers things—but it left scars. Your thirties were about building despite the rubble, creating stability in an unstable world, and figuring out what you actually wanted now that the script had been thrown out.

Your 40s ({{FORTIES_START}}-{{FORTIES_END}}): You're in this decade now, or just finishing it. COVID hit when you were forty-two, upending whatever normal you'd managed to construct. You handled it, because you handle everything. Your forties are your peak earning years, your highest authority at work, your last chance to course-correct anything that isn't working. Your kids, if you have them, are becoming adults. Your parents are aging. You're in the middle of everything, managing it all with the self-sufficiency you learned at age ten.

Your 50s ({{FIFTIES_START}}-{{FIFTIES_END}}): This will be the decade of reckoning. Retirement is visible on the horizon, which means the math has to work. Did you save enough? Is the 401(k) sufficient? Can you actually stop working, or will you need to keep going? Your health matters more now—the body you neglected in your forties will send bills in your fifties. Your role shifts from doing the work to mentoring those who will do it after you. Whether you like mentoring is irrelevant; it's your job now.

Your 60s ({{SIXTIES_START}} and beyond): Retirement, if it happens, won't look like your parents' retirement—endless golf and cruises funded by pensions. It'll be part-time work, consulting gigs, monetizing the expertise you've accumulated. You'll be healthy enough to stay active, probably, but healthcare costs will be a constant concern. You'll watch the world change in ways that feel increasingly alien. The technology that seemed cutting-edge in your thirties will be antiques. You'll be the elder who remembers the before times—before smartphones, before social media, before everything was connected. Younger people will find this baffling and slightly romantic.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly 3.3 million people born in 1978. The entire Gen X generation is about 65 million Americans, making you the smallest major generation—dwarfed by Boomers before and Millennials after. You're used to being overlooked. It's kind of your thing.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964), you're more pragmatic and less idealistic. Boomers believed they could change the world. You believed you could survive it. Boomers got pensions, affordable houses, and careers at single companies for thirty years. You got 401(k)s, housing that appreciated faster than your salary, and layoffs every time the economy hiccuped. You resent Boomers' advantages while respecting their work ethic. It's complicated.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996), you're slightly better positioned economically—you bought houses before they became impossible, established careers before the gig economy ate everything. But you're more similar than different. You share cynicism about institutions, frustration with economic precarity, and exhaustion with being blamed for problems you didn't create. Millennials just got it worse.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012), you're practically from another planet. They've never known life without the internet, smartphones, or social media. Their mental health struggles are visible in ways yours were hidden. They're more politically engaged than you ever were at their age, but also more anxious, more overwhelmed, more aware of how broken everything is. You want to help them but you don't know how.

Your life expectancy is around 78-80 years, which is actually lower than it was projected to be when you were born, thanks to the opioid crisis, 'deaths of despair,' and a healthcare system that prioritizes profit over patients. Your generation has worse health outcomes than Boomers did at your age. The American Dream didn't just fail financially—it failed physically.

But Gen X also has strengths that get overlooked. You're the most entrepreneurial generation, starting businesses at higher rates than Boomers or Millennials. You adapt to change faster because you've had to adapt constantly. You're resilient, self-sufficient, and capable. You don't need recognition—you just need to be left alone to get things done. Which, honestly, is the most Gen X sentence possible.

year_events: Louise Brown, the first test-tube baby, was born
Camp David Accords signed by Egypt and Israel
Pope John Paul II became the first non-Italian pope in 455 years
